purpose.summary: This policy establishes compliance standards and procedures for Internal Revenue Code Section 409A, which governs deferred compensation arrangements. The policy ensures the Company's compensation plans comply with Section 409A requirements to avoid significant tax penalties for the company and employees.
objectives: Establish compliance standards and procedures for IRC Section 409A
Ensure compensation plans comply with Section 409A requirements
Avoid significant tax penalties for the company and employees
Provide clear identification criteria for covered arrangements

appliesTo: All deferred compensation arrangements as defined by Section 409A
Sales compensation plans with payment timing features
All U.S.-based employees and independent contractors

definitions.definition: Any arrangement under which an employee has a legally binding right to compensation in one year that is payable in a subsequent year. This is broader than traditional 'voluntary deferral' plans.
Payments made by the 15th day of the third month following the end of the year in which the compensation vests are exempt from Section 409A.
A key employee as defined by Section 409A (generally officers, 5% owners, or highly compensated employees). Special payment delay rules apply.
Termination of employment as defined by Section 409A regulations (not necessarily same as company's termination definition).

The six events under Section 409A that can trigger deferred compensation payments: separation from service, disability, death, specified time/fixed schedule, change in control, or unforeseeable emergency.

provisions.title: Section 409A Overview
provisions.content: Section 409A of the Internal Revenue Code imposes strict requirements on non-qualified deferred compensation plans. It regulates when compensation can be deferred, when it must be paid, and what elections participants can make regarding payment timing.

subProvisions.title: Why Compliance Matters
subProvisions.content: Non-compliance with Section 409A results in severe consequences for employees:
items: Immediate income inclusion (even if payment not received)
Additional 20% penalty tax on deferred amounts
Interest penalties from original deferral date
No corresponding deduction for employer
These penalties can result in employees paying taxes exceeding 60% of deferred amounts

provisions.title: Identification of Section 409A Covered Arrangements
provisions.content: Guidelines for determining which arrangements are subject to Section 409A.

subProvisions.title: Arrangements Subject to Section 409A
subProvisions.content: The following arrangements ARE subject to Section 409A:
items: Commission payments made more than 2.5 months after year-end
Annual bonuses paid after March 15 of the following year
Multi-year incentive plans with payment delays
Severance payments exceeding 2x compensation limit
Retention bonuses with future payment dates
Change-in-control payments not meeting safe harbor exceptions

subProvisions.title: Arrangements Generally Exempt from Section 409A
subProvisions.content: The following arrangements are NOT subject to Section 409A (if properly structured):
items: Commissions/bonuses paid by March 15 following year earned
Qualified retirement plans (401(k), pension plans)
Stock options granted at fair market value
Restricted stock (not RSUs)
Severance up to 2x annual compensation (if paid within 2 years)
Vacation/PTO payouts

subProvisions.title: Gray Areas Requiring Analysis
subProvisions.content: Some arrangements require case-by-case analysis with Legal/Tax:
items: Clawback provisions with repayment timing beyond current year
Discretionary bonus programs with undefined payment timing
Earnout provisions in acquisition agreements
Amortized commission payments on multi-year contracts

provisions.title: Payment Timing Rules and Requirements
provisions.content: Specific rules governing when deferred compensation may be paid.

subProvisions.title: Short-Term Deferral Safe Harbor
subProvisions.content: To avoid Section 409A, compensation should be paid by the 15th day of the 3rd month following the end of the year in which it vests (becomes no longer subject to substantial risk of forfeiture).
items: 2025 commission earned and vested: Must pay by March 15, 2026
Annual bonus for FY 2025: Must pay by March 15, 2026
Commission on deal closed December 31, 2025: Must pay by March 15, 2026

subProvisions.title: Specified Employees - 6-Month Delay Rule
subProvisions.content: For 'specified employees' (key employees), payments triggered by separation from service must be delayed 6 months from separation date.
items: HR identifies specified employees annually (as of December 31)
List effective April 1 of following year
Separation-triggered payments delayed 6 months (or until death if earlier)
No interest accrues during 6-month delay

subProvisions.title: Permissible Payment Events
subProvisions.content: Section 409A limits payment triggers to these six events:
items: Separation from service
Death
Disability (as defined in regulations)
Specified time or fixed schedule (e.g., 'January 1, 2028')
Change in control of company (meeting safe harbor definition)
Unforeseeable emergency (very limited circumstances)
Plan documents must specify which of these events trigger payment. Vague language like 'when determined by the committee' is NOT compliant.

provisions.title: Plan Document Requirements
provisions.content: Requirements for compensation plan documents subject to Section 409A.

subProvisions.title: Required Plan Provisions
subProvisions.content: All compensation plans subject to Section 409A must include:
items: Specific payment timing tied to permissible payment events
No discretion to accelerate or delay payments (except as permitted by regulations)
Specified employee identification and 6-month delay provisions
Prohibition on impermissible acceleration
Section 409A savings clause
Definition of separation from service consistent with Section 409A

subProvisions.title: Section 409A Savings Clause
subProvisions.content: Every plan document should include a Section 409A savings clause such as: 'This Plan is intended to comply with or be exempt from Section 409A of the Internal Revenue Code. Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary, if any plan provision would cause a participant to incur additional tax or penalties under Section 409A, that provision shall be reformed to avoid such tax or penalties while maintaining, to the maximum extent possible, the original intent and economic benefit to the participant.'

subProvisions.title: Problematic Language to Avoid
subProvisions.content: Do NOT use these phrases in plan documents:
items: 'Payment at company's discretion'
'Payable when determined by committee'
'Upon termination, in company's sole discretion'
'As soon as administratively practicable' (too vague)
Instead use: 'Payable by March 15, 2026'
Instead use: 'Within 30 days following separation from service (subject to 6-month delay for specified employees)'
Instead use: 'In the first payroll period following [specific date]'

provisions.title: Annual Compliance Review Procedures
provisions.content: Annual review process to ensure ongoing Section 409A compliance.

subProvisions.title: Q4 Annual Review Process
subProvisions.content: Each year by November 30, Sales Compensation and Legal conduct Section 409A compliance review:
items: Step 1: Inventory All Compensation Plans - Identify all active sales compensation plans, document payment timing, flag plans with payments after March 15
Step 2: Section 409A Applicability Analysis - Determine which plans are subject to Section 409A, identify plans relying on short-term deferral exception
Step 3: Plan Document Review - Review payment timing language, verify Section 409A savings clauses, confirm specified employee provisions
Step 4: Operational Compliance Review - Review actual payment practices, identify payments made outside plan terms, assess specified employee payment delays
Step 5: Remediation Plan - Develop corrective action plan for any issues, prioritize plan document amendments, implement process improvements

subProvisions.title: New Plan Review
subProvisions.content: Before implementing any new compensation plan, Sales Compensation must:
items: Submit draft plan document to Legal for Section 409A review
Allow minimum 2 weeks for legal review
Obtain written approval from Legal before finalizing
Document approval in plan file

subProvisions.title: Specified Employee Identification
subProvisions.content: Annual process for identifying specified employees:
items: HR runs specified employee analysis as of December 31
Applies IRS criteria: officers, 5% owners, top-paid employees
List finalized by January 31
Effective April 1 for following 12 months
Payroll flagged to apply 6-month delay for specified employees

provisions.title: Penalties for Non-Compliance
provisions.content: Consequences of Section 409A non-compliance for employees and company.

subProvisions.title: Employee Penalties
subProvisions.content: Employees subject to deferred compensation in violation of Section 409A face:
items: Immediate income inclusion of all deferred amounts (even if not yet paid)
20% additional tax penalty on deferred compensation
Interest penalties calculated from year of deferral
Effective tax rate can exceed 60% of deferred amount

subProvisions.title: Company Impact
subProvisions.content: While Section 409A penalties apply primarily to employees, company faces:
items: Reputational risk and employee relations damage
Potential loss of tax deduction if amount never paid
Increased reporting complexity (Form W-2 corrections)
Possible litigation from affected employees
IRS scrutiny of other compensation arrangements

subProvisions.title: Correction Programs
subProvisions.content: IRS provides limited correction programs for Section 409A errors:
items: Document failures can sometimes be corrected retroactively
Operational failures have narrow correction windows
Early detection is critical for effective correction
Not all failures are correctable

provisions.title: Roles and Responsibilities
provisions.content: Clearly defined roles for all parties involved in Section 409A compliance.

subProvisions.title: Sales Compensation Team
subProvisions.content: Primary responsibilities:
items: Design plans to avoid Section 409A where possible
Submit new plans for legal review before implementation
Maintain inventory of all compensation arrangements
Process payments according to compliant timing
Participate in annual compliance review

subProvisions.title: Legal/Tax Department
subProvisions.content: Compliance oversight:
items: Provide Section 409A training to Sales Compensation
Review all new plan documents for compliance
Conduct annual Section 409A compliance audit
Advise on correction programs if issues identified
Update policies as regulations change

subProvisions.title: Human Resources
subProvisions.content: Employee management:
items: Identify specified employees annually
Communicate specified employee status to affected individuals
Coordinate with Payroll on 6-month payment delays
Maintain specified employee lists

subProvisions.title: Payroll
subProvisions.content: Payment processing:
items: Flag specified employees in payroll system
Apply 6-month payment delays for separation-triggered payments
Report deferred compensation on Form W-2
Process payments according to documented schedules

subProvisions.title: Finance
subProvisions.content: Financial management:
items: Ensure proper accounting for deferred compensation
Coordinate with Tax on reporting requirements
Maintain records of deferred compensation liabilities
